abstract: The art of admitting mistakes without accepting blame will be on display at a Congressional hearing Wednesday.
snippet: The art of admitting mistakes without accepting blame will be on display at a Congressional hearing Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As America recovers from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, some of the nation’s chief executives are offering that rarest of statements  an apology.

headline.main: For Bankers, Saying ‘Sorry’ Has Its Perils
headline.print_headline: For Bankers, Saying ‘Sorry’ Has Its Perils

byline.original: By Andrew Martin and Micheline Maynard

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.
snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Bank of America for a second time over its takeover of Merrill Lynch, accusing the bank of failing to disclose huge losses at Merrill before shareholders voted on the merger.

headline.main: S.E.C. Sues Bank of America (Again) on Merrill

abstract: Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008.
snippet: Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Summoned to Capitol Hill to explain their companies’ roles in the worst economic downturn since the Depression, leaders of four big Wall Street banks offered a largely clinical take on the financial crisis on Wednesday, pointing to lapses in risk management and government regulation but offering little sense of the turmoil’s human toll.

headline.main: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take a Meeker Tone on Capitol Hill
headline.print_headline: Voices That Dominate Wall Street Take a Meeker Tone on Capitol Hill

abstract: The bipartisan commission established by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis summoned the heads of four large Wall Street banks to defend their lending, risk management and pay practices and explain their role in the biggest economic downturn since the Depression.
snippet: The bipartisan commission established by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis summoned the heads of four large Wall Street banks to defend their lending, risk management and pay practices and explain their role in the biggest eco...
lead_paragraph: The bipartisan commission established by Congress to examine the causes of the financial crisis summoned the heads of four large Wall Street banks on Wednesday to defend their lending, risk management and pay practices and explain their companies’ role in the biggest economic downturn since the Depression, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline.main: For Bankers, Hearing Requires Walking a Fine Line

abstract: DealBook is live-blogging the hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, where Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America are testifying about the financial crisis.
snippet: DealBook is live-blogging the hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, where Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America are testifying about t...
lead_paragraph: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission heard testimony about the financial crisis from four of the nation’s leading bankers: Lloyd C. Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, John J. Mack of Morgan Stanley and Brian T. Moynihan of Bank of America. (Watch the live video here, via C-Span 2.) DealBook’s Zachery Kouwe live-blogged the hearing, with the most recent entries at the top:

headline.main: Live-Blogging 4 Top Bankers on Capitol Hill

abstract: The heads of Wall Street’s largest banks faced skeptical questions on Wednesday about executive pay and the failures of regulation from the bipartisan commission established to examine the causes of the biggest downturn since the Depression.
snippet: The heads of Wall Street’s largest banks faced skeptical questions on Wednesday about executive pay and the failures of regulation from the bipartisan commission established to examine the causes of the biggest downturn since the Depression.
lead_paragraph: The heads of Wall Street’s largest banks faced skeptical questions on Wednesday about executive pay and the failures of regulation from the bipartisan commission established to examine the causes of the biggest downturn since the Depression, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington. Tensions flared as commission members retraced the events leading to the near-collapse of the financial system in 2008 and pressed bankers on whether they or their employees had behaved unethically.

headline.main: Bankers Face Tough Questions at Crisis Hearing

abstract: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.
snippet: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.
lead_paragraph: The first public hearing of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission featured the testimony of four top bank executives.

abstract: The former White House chief of staff and the Texas financier jointly extolled the virtues of natural gas in a news conference.
snippet: The former White House chief of staff and the Texas financier jointly extolled the virtues of natural gas in a news conference.
lead_paragraph: T. Boone Pickens, the billionaire Texas financier, and John Podesta, President Bill Clinton’s White House chief of staff, are not exactly political soul mates.

headline.main: Podesta and Pickens Stump for Natural Gas

abstract: Google, PhoneTag and AT&T offer services that transcribe voice mail messages into text.
snippet: Google, PhoneTag and AT&T offer services that transcribe voice mail messages into text.
lead_paragraph: Visual voice mail is great if you want to know who sent a message before you go through the trouble of dialing your voice mail service to hear it.

headline.main: Voice Mail You Can Read: It Saves Time (at the Risk of Meaning)
